title: Hanban and CRI Broadcasting Confucius Institute funds the establishment of a Confucius Classroom at CRI in Sfax (Linked to Project ID#31221)
description: In 2009, the Confucius Institute Headquarters (Hanban) and China Radio International Broadcasting Confucius Institute established the Confucius Classroom at CRI in Sfax, Tunisia. The classroom was also established by the Tunisia-China Friendship CRI Audience Club and the Universal House "Sfax". It was the first Confucius Classroom established by the CRI Broadcasting Confucius Institute in the Arab world. The classroom was designed to use radio to help Tunisians learn the Chinese language. The Confucius Classroom was inaugurated on September 12, 2009. At the inauguration of the Confucius Classroom, the Chinese Embassy to Tunisia donated books and CDs to the Confucius Classroom, as captured by linked project ID#31221.
staff_comments: The Chinese name for the Confucius Classroom is 突尼斯斯法克斯ＣＲＩ广播孔子课堂. According to Hanban's website ('Confucius Classroom at CRI in Sfax'), the agreement for the Confucius Classroom was signed on November 4, 2009. However, it is clear that the classroom was formally inaugurated before this point.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban and CRI Broadcasting Confucius Institute funds the establishment of a Confucius Classroom at CRI in Sfax (Linked to Project ID#31221)

# Description
In 2009, the Confucius Institute Headquarters (Hanban) and China Radio International Broadcasting Confucius Institute established the Confucius Classroom at CRI in Sfax, Tunisia. The classroom was also established by the Tunisia-China Friendship CRI Audience Club and the Universal House "Sfax". It was the first Confucius Classroom established by the CRI Broadcasting Confucius Institute in the Arab world. The classroom was designed to use radio to help Tunisians learn the Chinese language. The Confucius Classroom was inaugurated on September 12, 2009. At the inauguration of the Confucius Classroom, the Chinese Embassy to Tunisia donated books and CDs to the Confucius Classroom, as captured by linked project ID#31221.
justification: Project focuses on language education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Classroom for Chinese language education, cultural exchange focus

title: Chinese Government provides a grant for the Aquaculture Project
description: The Chinese Government provided a grant to the Government of Tunisia for the 2009 Aquaculture Project. The Chinese Government donated aquaculture equipment to Tunisia, dispatched Chinese aquaculture experts to the country, conducted on-site technical training, and invited officials and technicians from Tunisia's Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources to China for inspections and training, in order to bring freshwater water fish farming technology to Tunisia. The project was also intended to help protect Tunisian reservoirs, canals, and the environment at large.  In early January 2009, a team of 2 Chinese experts from the freshwater aquaculture technical team arrived in Tunisia and began their 8-month technical service and training stint in Tunisia. Additionally, all materials from the Chinese Government were delivered to the project site. On December 21, 2009, the Chinese Government signed a handover certificate with the Government of Tunisia for the completion of the project.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 中国援助突尼斯水产养殖项目.'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that the grant for this project was signed in 2009, only that the project began and ended in that year.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides a grant for the Aquaculture Project

# Description
The Chinese Government provided a grant to the Government of Tunisia for the 2009 Aquaculture Project. The Chinese Government donated aquaculture equipment to Tunisia, dispatched Chinese aquaculture experts to the country, conducted on-site technical training, and invited officials and technicians from Tunisia's Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources to China for inspections and training, in order to bring freshwater water fish farming technology to Tunisia. The project was also intended to help protect Tunisian reservoirs, canals, and the environment at large.  In early January 2009, a team of 2 Chinese experts from the freshwater aquaculture technical team arrived in Tunisia and began their 8-month technical service and training stint in Tunisia. Additionally, all materials from the Chinese Government were delivered to the project site. On December 21, 2009, the Chinese Government signed a handover certificate with the Government of Tunisia for the completion of the project.
justification: Project focuses on technology transfer and capacity building in aquaculture, with environmental protection as a secondary benefit
evidence: Aquaculture equipment donation, technical training, freshwater fish farming technology transfer, environmental protection mentioned as secondary goal

title: China Eximbank provides a $80.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for Railcar Acquisition Project
description: On October 22, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer Tunisiens (SNCFT) — a state-owned railway operator in Tunisia — signed a $80,148,694.70 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement for the Railcar Acquisition Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The Tunisian Chamber of Deputies ratified the loan agreement and approved the issuance of a sovereign guarantee from the Government of Tunisia in support of the loan on January 12, 2010. President of Tunisia Zine El Abidine Ben Ali then approved the law and the sovereign guarantee on January 20, 2010 via Law n ° 2010-1.  The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a $93.66 million USD commercial contract with China South Locomotive & Rolling Stock Corp., Ltd, a subsidiary of the state-owned CSR Group, which was signed on March 30, 2009, for the provision of electric units (EMUs). It also included the commissioning of the railcars and the training of Tunisian technicians on the maintenance of the railcars. CRS Nanjing Puzhen Co., Ltd. was the specific company responsible for construction of the railcars. Voith Turbo (a division of the Voith Group) supplied 42 RailPacks with T212bre turbo transmission, SK/KE 485 final drives, roof-mounted cooling systems and cardan shafts, and Schaku couplers for the project to act as emergency replacements.  The purpose of the project was to acquire 20 railcars. 12 of these railcars were designed to serve the Tunis-Beja, Jendouba-Ghardimaou, and Tunis-Bizerte railway lines. The other 8 railcars were design to serve the Tunis-Gafsa, Gabes-Tunis, Tunis-Mahdia, and Tunis-Kalaa Khasba railway lines. The new railcars had a speed of 160 km/h, which would greatly reduce travel times. The acquisition of new railcars was part of the renewal of the Tunisia's national rail transportation, which sought to modernize Tunisia's old train fleet.   The first railcar was shipped to Tunisia in February 2012. 6 of the railcars were originally scheduled to arrive in Tunisia on July 5, 2012; two railcars had already been delivered and were already in use in Tunisia at that time. The railcars were officially put into commercial operation in a ceremony held on December 17, 2012.  Then, in August 2017, the CEO of SNCFT, Sarra Rejeb, announced that she suspected mismanagement within the company and called for an investigation into the purchase of the 20 railcars. She argued that it was an unsuccessful deal, since the railcars' quality was "mediocre" and 12 of them had been damaged and rendered non-functional.
staff_comments: 1. The French project title is Projet d’acquisition de 20 autorails pour le transport des voyageurs sur les grandes lignes. The Chinese project title is 购动车组项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides a $80.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for Railcar Acquisition Project

# Description
On October 22, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer Tunisiens (SNCFT) — a state-owned railway operator in Tunisia — signed a $80,148,694.70 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement for the Railcar Acquisition Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The Tunisian Chamber of Deputies ratified the loan agreement and approved the issuance of a sovereign guarantee from the Government of Tunisia in support of the loan on January 12, 2010. President of Tunisia Zine El Abidine Ben Ali then approved the law and the sovereign guarantee on January 20, 2010 via Law n ° 2010-1.  The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a $93.66 million USD commercial contract with China South Locomotive & Rolling Stock Corp., Ltd, a subsidiary of the state-owned CSR Group, which was signed on March 30, 2009, for the provision of electric units (EMUs). It also included the commissioning of the railcars and the training of Tunisian technicians on the maintenance of the railcars. CRS Nanjing Puzhen Co., Ltd. was the specific company responsible for construction of the railcars. Voith Turbo (a division of the Voith Group) supplied 42 RailPacks with T212bre turbo transmission, SK/KE 485 final drives, roof-mounted cooling systems and cardan shafts, and Schaku couplers for the project to act as emergency replacements.  The purpose of the project was to acquire 20 railcars. 12 of these railcars were designed to serve the Tunis-Beja, Jendouba-Ghardimaou, and Tunis-Bizerte railway lines. The other 8 railcars were design to serve the Tunis-Gafsa, Gabes-Tunis, Tunis-Mahdia, and Tunis-Kalaa Khasba railway lines. The new railcars had a speed of 160 km/h, which would greatly reduce travel times. The acquisition of new railcars was part of the renewal of the Tunisia's national rail transportation, which sought to modernize Tunisia's old train fleet.   The first railcar was shipped to Tunisia in February 2012. 6 of the railcars were originally scheduled to arrive in Tunisia on July 5, 2012; two railcars had already been delivered and were already in use in Tunisia at that time. The railcars were officially put into commercial operation in a ceremony held on December 17, 2012.  Then, in August 2017, the CEO of SNCFT, Sarra Rejeb, announced that she suspected mismanagement within the company and called for an investigation into the purchase of the 20 railcars. She argued that it was an unsuccessful deal, since the railcars' quality was "mediocre" and 12 of them had been damaged and rendered non-functional.
justification: Project focuses on railcar acquisition for transportation modernization without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Acquisition of 20 railcars for national rail transportation, modernization of train fleet, no specific mention of environmental or energy transition benefits

title: MOFCOM provides a RMB 25 million grant for the El Menzah VI Sport and Cultural Center Rehabilitation Project
description: On March 31, 2008, the Chinese Government the Government of Tunisia signed an exchange of letters, commissioning a feasibility study by Chinese experts for the El Menzah VI Sport and Cultural Center Rehabilitation Project. President of Tunisia Zine El Abidine Ben Ali ratified this exchange of letters via Decree n° 2008-2971 on September 8, 2008. The project design contract was signed on April 17, 2009. Then, on November 9 and 12, 2009, the two governments signed an exchange of letters regarding the implementation of the El Menzah VI Sport and Cultural Center Rehabilitation Project. This exchange of letters was approved on April 20, 2010 via Law n ° 2010-19 by the Tunisian Government, and then President of Tunisia Zine El Abidine Ben Ali ratified this exchange of letters via Decree n° 2010-1453 on June 14, 2010.  Then, on December 13, 2013 and December 16, 2013, the two governments signed another exchange of letters for the provision of a Chinese Government grant for a study on the project. This exchange of letters was was ratified by the Tunisian Government via Decree n° 2014-2262 on June 24, 2014; the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tunisia was responsible for executing the agreement. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of funding. It committed RMB 25 million of grant funding in total to support the implementation of this project.  The purpose of the project was to renovate and upgrade a sports and cultural center in the city of Ariana that was constructed during the late 1980s and completed in 1990 with financing from a Chinese Government loan. The center included a 500-seat multifunctional theater, an indoor swimming pool, multiple classrooms, and outdoor sports fields. The center falls under the supervision of the Ministry of Youth Sports of Tunisia. All of these facilities were renovated under the project. The center was over 5231 square meters. All of these facilities were renovated under the project.   China Dalian International Economic & Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. (中国大连国际经济技术合作集团有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Beijing Institute of Architectural Design (Group) Co., Ltd. (BIAD) and Shenyang Engineering & Supervision Consulting Co., Ltd. served in a consortium for the project's management. BIAD also worked as the project's survey and design unit.  The project implementation agreement was signed on April 28, 2016. Project implementation began in October 2016. It was scheduled for completion in October 2017. It went into review and inspection on September 17, 2017. The formal project handover ceremony was held on November 17, 2017.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the  El Menzah VI Sport and Cultural Center Renovation Project or the  El Menzah VI Sport and Cultural Center Upgrade Project. The French project title is Projet d’entretien du centre culturel et sportif des jeunes d’El Menzah 6 or la rénovation de la maison des jeunes d’El Menzah 6 or Projet de rénovation du Centre culturel et sportif des Jeunes d'El Menzah VI. The Arabic project title is Ariana or المركز الثقافي الرياضي. The Chinese project is 芒扎青体中心升级改造项目 or 援突尼斯青年文化体育中心升级改造项目. Decree n° 2014-2262 refers to ‘grant of a loan intended to finance the studies about the project of rehabilitation the cultural and sportive center of El Menzah VI.’ However, most other sources refer to this project as being financed with a grant. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:

This exchange of letters was approved on April 20, 2010 via Law n ° 2010-19 by the Tunisian Government, and then President of Tunisia Zine El Abidine Ben Ali ratified this exchange of letters via Decree n° 2010-1453 on June 14, 2010.  Then, on December 13, 2013 and December 16, 2013, the two governments signed another exchange of letters for the provision of a Chinese Government grant for a study on the project. This exchange of letters was was ratified by the Tunisian Government via Decree n° 2014-2262 on June 24, 2014; the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tunisia was responsible for executing the agreement. title: Chinese National People's Congress donates computer equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies
description: On January 10, 2009, the 45th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the People's Republic of China and Tunisia, the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China donated computer equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies in a ceremony held in the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies' building. At the ceremony, representatives from Tunisia and China signed a handover certificate for the donation.

At the ceremony, representatives from Tunisia and China signed a handover certificate for the donation.

title: Chinese Government donates computer and multimedia equipment worth RMB 37 million
description: On December 15, 2009, Li Beifen, the Chinese Ambassador to Tunisia and Elyès Kasri, Director General for the Americas and Asia of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Tunisia, signed a handover certificate for the Chinese Government's provision of two batches of computer equipment worth RMB 37 million (7.4 million Tunisian dinars) to the Government of Tunisia. This donation included 6,600 computers and multimedia equipment and was intended improve the government's office conditions.

title: ICBC provides loan for 600 MW Ayas Supercritical Coal-Fired Power Plant Project
description: In 2009, ICBC and AYAS Enerji (AYAS Enerji Üretim ve Ticaret A.S.) — a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary of the Turkish armed forces pension fund  (OYAK)— signed a loan agreement for the 600 MW Ayas Supercritical Coal-Fired Power Plant Project. The proceeds of this loan were to be used to finance an EPC contract between China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation (CMEC) and Germany’s Evonik Steag Gmb Corporation, which was signed on August 19, 2009. The face value of the loan is unknown.   This $750 million project involves the construction of a 600MW supercritical coal-fired power plant near Sugözü village in Yumurtalık district and Adana province.   In April 2009, the project received a license for an 800 MW plant from the Energy Market Regulatory Authority (EPDK or EMRA). Site preparation work was reported as completed, and conducted by EKTON Construction & Logistics. Then, on September 1, 2009, the project began implementation. However, it encountered implementation difficulties. In March 2015, Ayas Enerji held an environmental permitting public hearing in Sugözü. Activists and community members with Adana Environmental Platform protested at the meeting. The project's license was challenged due to a high concentration of proposed plants in the area. According to EMRA, the plant was under construction and 19% complete as of January 2019. Satellite photography from plant shows only ground-clearing activity at the project site between January 2019 and June 2019.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is（AYAS）1×600MW超临界电站项目 or 土耳其Ayas电站. 2. In 2009, OYAK, the Turkish armed forces pension fund, bought a 49% stake in AYAS Enerji. It later bought an additional 51% of the company to make it a wholly-owned subsidiary. OYAK subsequently sold 50% of the company to AES Entek, which OYAK described as a 'joint venture of the Koç Group and AES.'3. The face value of the ICBC loan is unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes that the $750 million project is being financed according to a debt-to-equity ratio of 70:30. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
ICBC provides loan for 600 MW Ayas Supercritical Coal-Fired Power Plant Project

# Description
In 2009, ICBC and AYAS Enerji (AYAS Enerji Üretim ve Ticaret A.S.) — a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary of the Turkish armed forces pension fund  (OYAK)— signed a loan agreement for the 600 MW Ayas Supercritical Coal-Fired Power Plant Project. The proceeds of this loan were to be used to finance an EPC contract between China National Machinery and Equipment Import & Export Corporation (CMEC) and Germany’s Evonik Steag Gmb Corporation, which was signed on August 19, 2009. The face value of the loan is unknown.   This $750 million project involves the construction of a 600MW supercritical coal-fired power plant near Sugözü village in Yumurtalık district and Adana province.   In April 2009, the project received a license for an 800 MW plant from the Energy Market Regulatory Authority (EPDK or EMRA). Site preparation work was reported as completed, and conducted by EKTON Construction & Logistics. Then, on September 1, 2009, the project began implementation. However, it encountered implementation difficulties. In March 2015, Ayas Enerji held an environmental permitting public hearing in Sugözü. Activists and community members with Adana Environmental Platform protested at the meeting. The project's license was challenged due to a high concentration of proposed plants in the area. According to EMRA, the plant was under construction and 19% complete as of January 2019. Satellite photography from plant shows only ground-clearing activity at the project site between January 2019 and June 2019.
justification: Project is explicitly a coal-fired power plant, which is environmentally harmful and inhibits energy transition
evidence: 600 MW supercritical coal-fired power plant, coal-fired technology specified, environmental protests noted

title: CDB provides $4 billion loan for Phase 1 of Galkynysh Gas Field Project (Linked to Project ID#41905)
description: On June 25, 2009, China Development Bank signed a $4 billion loan agreement with Turkmengaz (the state-owned natural gas company of Turkmenistan) for Phase 1 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (captured via Project ID#40393). The loan reportedly carried a 7-year maturity and 4.8426% interest rate; it was secured by natural gas exports to China (through a parallel gas sales agreement with PetroChina). As part of the transaction, Turkmengaz reportedly agreed to supply China with up to 40 billion cubic meters/year of natural gas for 30 years. Turkmengaz agreed to use the revenue it earned from a natural gas supply contract as a source of collateral. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance an EPC contract between Turkmengaz and CNPC, which was signed on December 29, 2009.   The purpose of the project’s first phase was to help develop the Galkynysh Gas Field (also known as South Yolotan–Osman Field). CNPC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Phase 1 commenced on February 28, 2011. The 1st gas well was drilled on May 20, 2011. Phase 1 was successfully completed and put into commercial operation on September 4, 2013. In March 2011, China Development Bank signed a loan-for-gas framework agreement with Turkmengaz for Phase 2 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project.   Nine month later, in April 2011, China Development Bank and Turkmengaz signed a $4.1 billion loan agreement for Phase 2 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (captured via Project ID#41905). The loan carried a 10-year maturity, a 3-year grace period, and an interest rate of 4.8855%; it was also reportedly secured by (i.e. collateralized against) natural gas export receipts to China (via PetroChina). The purpose of Phase 2 was to build facilities at the Galkynysh Gas Field that would process 30 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year. Phase 2 entered implementation on May 8, 2014. It was originally expected to reach completion in 2021. As of June 2021, the Government of Turkmenistan reported that it had full repaid both of the China Development Bank loans that were issued for the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (i.e. neither loan had any outstanding principal amount).
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the South Yolotan–Osman Field Project and the Ioujno-Elotenshoie Gas Field Project. The Russian project title is Газовое месторождение Галкыныш. 2. Some sources refer to a supplementary agreement covering CNPC's exploration and production activities at Bagitiyarlik, where the company had a license to produce up to 30 Bcm/year, and a separate contract through which Turkmengaz agreed to deliver 10 Bcm/year to CNPC. 3. The price at which the natural gas was sold to PetroChina in unknown. This issue warrants further investigation. 4. Some sources suggest that the CDB loan for Phase 1 was worth $3 billion rather than $4 billion. However, the borrowing institution claims on its website that it borrowing $8.1 billion into total from CDB, so AidData has coded the face value of the Phase 1 loan as $4 billion for the time being. This issue warrants further investigation. 4. Some sources suggest that the CDB loan for Phase 2 was issued in September 2013 rather than April 2011. This issue warrants further investigation.5. The 2009 CDB loan's interest rate (4.8426%) and the 2011 CDB loan's interest rate (4.8855%) are drawn from the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (see https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0).
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
CDB provides $4 billion loan for Phase 1 of Galkynysh Gas Field Project (Linked to Project ID#41905)

# Description
On June 25, 2009, China Development Bank signed a $4 billion loan agreement with Turkmengaz (the state-owned natural gas company of Turkmenistan) for Phase 1 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (captured via Project ID#40393). The loan reportedly carried a 7-year maturity and 4.8426% interest rate; it was secured by natural gas exports to China (through a parallel gas sales agreement with PetroChina). As part of the transaction, Turkmengaz reportedly agreed to supply China with up to 40 billion cubic meters/year of natural gas for 30 years. Turkmengaz agreed to use the revenue it earned from a natural gas supply contract as a source of collateral. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance an EPC contract between Turkmengaz and CNPC, which was signed on December 29, 2009.   The purpose of the project’s first phase was to help develop the Galkynysh Gas Field (also known as South Yolotan–Osman Field). CNPC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Phase 1 commenced on February 28, 2011. The 1st gas well was drilled on May 20, 2011. Phase 1 was successfully completed and put into commercial operation on September 4, 2013. In March 2011, China Development Bank signed a loan-for-gas framework agreement with Turkmengaz for Phase 2 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project.   Nine month later, in April 2011, China Development Bank and Turkmengaz signed a $4.1 billion loan agreement for Phase 2 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (captured via Project ID#41905). The loan carried a 10-year maturity, a 3-year grace period, and an interest rate of 4.8855%; it was also reportedly secured by (i.e. collateralized against) natural gas export receipts to China (via PetroChina). The purpose of Phase 2 was to build facilities at the Galkynysh Gas Field that would process 30 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year. Phase 2 entered implementation on May 8, 2014. It was originally expected to reach completion in 2021. As of June 2021, the Government of Turkmenistan reported that it had full repaid both of the China Development Bank loans that were issued for the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (i.e. neither loan had any outstanding principal amount).
justification: Project focuses on development of natural gas field and processing facilities, increasing fossil fuel production capacity
evidence: Development of Galkynysh Gas Field, natural gas export focus, processing capacity of 30 billion cubic meters/year

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 450 million government concessional loan for Phase 3 of Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project (Linked to Project ID#40332, #40214, #88175, #88176)
description: In December 2002, the Chinese Government and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) committing RMB 40 million through a grant (captured via Project #88175) and an interest-free loan (captured via Project #88176). Then, in June 2004, Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Telecommunications and Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. signed an RMB 40 million ($4.8 million) commercial contract for Phase 1 of the Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project. The commercial contract was fully financed with the ETCA proceeds committed in December 2002.  In 2005, Turkmen Prime Minister Atamyrat Berdiyev announced that the Chinese Government was planning to give the Government of Turkmenistan another soft credit line worth RMB 650 million to carry out telecommunications projects (captured via Project #42014). Then, in April 2006, the Governments of Turkmenistan and the Chinese Government signed a preferential loan framework agreement that set out the terms and conditions of borrowing for these telecommunications project. In December 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank) and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an RMB 200 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of a Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project (captured via Project #40332). The exact borrowing terms are unknown.  Then, in 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an RMB 450 million government concessional loan for Phase 3 of a Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project (Project #57778). The exact borrowing terms are unknown.   The purpose of Phase 1 was to establish a radio-telephone communication network in Ashgabat by modernizing inter-station communication links. Under the terms of its Phase 1 contract, Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. also agreed to build build the Euro-Asian fiber cable’s extensions to Ashgabat, Anau, Yashlyk, Kaahka, Dushak and Tejen. Additionally, Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. agreed to mount digital automatic telephone stations in Akhal and in Lebap regionvas well as a digital automatic telephone station in Turkmenabat.  The purpose of Phase 2 was to acquire telecommunication equipment and spare parts for the Ministry of Communications of Turkmenistan. The equipment was to be used for the the construction of digital automatic telephone exchanges (строительство новых цифровых АТС), the construction of Farap-Turkmenabat-Atamurat-Magdanly, Tejen-Serahs and Ashgabat-Dashoguz fiber-optic communication lines (волоконно-оптических линий связи «Фарап–Туркменабат–Атамурат–Магданлы» и «Теджен–Серахс» и «Ашхабад–Дашогуз»), the expansion of the capacity of the Turkmenistan's national cellular communication network (TM CELL) [расширение емкости Национальной сети сотовой связи «TM CELL»], and the expansion of CDMA radio access network (сети радиодоступа стандарта CDMA). Phase 2 involved the installation of 84 basic stations in Asgabat and other regions, including the installations of stations along the Turkmenbasy-Asgabat-Mary-Turkmenabat road, in order to meet Turkmenistan's growing demand for mobile communication. The number of users of the CDMA radio access network was expected to rise by 10,000 upon completion of Phase 2. 10 basic stations were to be installed in Asgabat and its suburbs, Coganly, Bekrewe, Bagyr and Bedew, and and in the Arcabil settlement, the town of Abadan, and in Gokdepe District. The fiber optic communication lines were to link the large and small towns of Turkmenistan, and the Farap-Turkmenabat-Atamyrat-Magdanly fibre-optic line was to be 450 kilometers upon completion. Once all the stations reached their full capacity, the new fibre-optic line was expected to provide high-quality digital communications for 14 large localities in the south of the Lebap Region. Additionally, the Tejen-Sarahs fibre-optic telecommunication main line was expected to be 130 kilometers long when it was done.  Phase 3 involved the acquisition of telecommunications equipment for Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Communications. According to a 2012 annual report published by the State Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of Turkmenistan, Phase 3 entered implementation. However, its precise implementation start date is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. The Russian project title is третьего этапа проекта реконструкции сетей связи or телекоммуникационного оборудования.2. It is not clear if ZTE, Huawei, or both companies were involved in the implementation of Phase 2 and Phase 3. This issue requires further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 450 million government concessional loan for Phase 3 of Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project (Linked to Project ID#40332, #40214, #88175, #88176)

# Description
In December 2002, the Chinese Government and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) committing RMB 40 million through a grant (captured via Project #88175) and an interest-free loan (captured via Project #88176). Then, in June 2004, Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Telecommunications and Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. signed an RMB 40 million ($4.8 million) commercial contract for Phase 1 of the Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project. The commercial contract was fully financed with the ETCA proceeds committed in December 2002.  In 2005, Turkmen Prime Minister Atamyrat Berdiyev announced that the Chinese Government was planning to give the Government of Turkmenistan another soft credit line worth RMB 650 million to carry out telecommunications projects (captured via Project #42014). Then, in April 2006, the Governments of Turkmenistan and the Chinese Government signed a preferential loan framework agreement that set out the terms and conditions of borrowing for these telecommunications project. In December 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank) and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an RMB 200 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of a Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project (captured via Project #40332). The exact borrowing terms are unknown.  Then, in 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an RMB 450 million government concessional loan for Phase 3 of a Telecommunications Equipment Acquisition Project (Project #57778). The exact borrowing terms are unknown.   The purpose of Phase 1 was to establish a radio-telephone communication network in Ashgabat by modernizing inter-station communication links. Under the terms of its Phase 1 contract, Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. also agreed to build build the Euro-Asian fiber cable’s extensions to Ashgabat, Anau, Yashlyk, Kaahka, Dushak and Tejen. Additionally, Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. agreed to mount digital automatic telephone stations in Akhal and in Lebap regionvas well as a digital automatic telephone station in Turkmenabat.  The purpose of Phase 2 was to acquire telecommunication equipment and spare parts for the Ministry of Communications of Turkmenistan. The equipment was to be used for the the construction of digital automatic telephone exchanges (строительство новых цифровых АТС), the construction of Farap-Turkmenabat-Atamurat-Magdanly, Tejen-Serahs and Ashgabat-Dashoguz fiber-optic communication lines (волоконно-оптических линий связи «Фарап–Туркменабат–Атамурат–Магданлы» и «Теджен–Серахс» и «Ашхабад–Дашогуз»), the expansion of the capacity of the Turkmenistan's national cellular communication network (TM CELL) [расширение емкости Национальной сети сотовой связи «TM CELL»], and the expansion of CDMA radio access network (сети радиодоступа стандарта CDMA). Phase 2 involved the installation of 84 basic stations in Asgabat and other regions, including the installations of stations along the Turkmenbasy-Asgabat-Mary-Turkmenabat road, in order to meet Turkmenistan's growing demand for mobile communication. The number of users of the CDMA radio access network was expected to rise by 10,000 upon completion of Phase 2. 10 basic stations were to be installed in Asgabat and its suburbs, Coganly, Bekrewe, Bagyr and Bedew, and and in the Arcabil settlement, the town of Abadan, and in Gokdepe District. The fiber optic communication lines were to link the large and small towns of Turkmenistan, and the Farap-Turkmenabat-Atamyrat-Magdanly fibre-optic line was to be 450 kilometers upon completion. Once all the stations reached their full capacity, the new fibre-optic line was expected to provide high-quality digital communications for 14 large localities in the south of the Lebap Region. Additionally, the Tejen-Sarahs fibre-optic telecommunication main line was expected to be 130 kilometers long when it was done.  Phase 3 involved the acquisition of telecommunications equipment for Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Communications. According to a 2012 annual report published by the State Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of Turkmenistan, Phase 3 entered implementation. However, its precise implementation start date is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Telecommunications equipment acquisition, fiber-optic communication lines, digital automatic telephone exchanges, cellular network expansion
